review.title: Leveraging Over Priors for Boosting Control of Prosthetic Hands
review.abstract: The Electromyography (EMG) signal is the electrical activity produced by cells of skeletal muscles in order to provide a movement. The non-invasive prosthetic hand works with several electrodes, placed on the stump of an amputee, that record this signal. In order to favour the control of prosthesis, the EMG signal is analyzed with algorithms based on machine learning theory to decide the movement that the subject is going to do. In order to obtain a significant control of the prosthesis and avoid mismatch between desired and performed movements, a long training period is needed when we use the traditional algorithm of machine learning (i.e. Support Vector Machines). An actual challenge in this field concerns the reduction of the time necessary for an amputee to learn how to use the prosthesis. Recently, several algorithms that exploit a form of prior knowledge have been proposed. In general, we refer to prior knowledge as a past experience available in the form of models. In our case an amputee, that attempts to perform some movements with the prosthesis, could use experience from different subjects that are already able to perform those movements. The aim of this work is to verify, with a computational investigation, if for an amputee this kind of previous experience is useful in order to reduce the training time and boost the prosthetic control. Furthermore, we want to understand if and how the final results change when the previous knowledge of intact or amputated subjects is used for a new amputee. Our experiments indicate that: (1) the use of experience, from other subjects already trained to perform a task, makes us able to reduce the training time of about an order of magnitude; (2) it seems that an amputee that tries to learn to use the prosthesis doesn't reach different results when he/she exploits previous experience of amputees or intact.

sections.heading: 1.1 Contributions of this thesis
sections.text: This thesis deals with the control of prostheses using an approach based on machine learning, as previous work in this field suggests ([8], [9], [10]). Our goal is to increase the level of dexterity in the use of prostheses, in order to favor a natural form of control. In this work, the prosthesis we refer to consists of several electrodes that collect the electromyography signal (EMG), i.e. the electrical manifestation of muscle activation. Using machine learning techniques, we analyze this signal to determine the most likely motion that the subject wants to execute. Currently, machine learning algorithms are successful in this area, and not only for their generality and ability to expand traditional theory. One of the most famous definitions of machine learning is provided by Tom M. Mitchell and can be summarized as follows: a computer program is said to learn when its performance is improved in a given task.

sections.heading: 1.2 Outline
sections.text: The content of this paper is broken down as follows: In Chapter 2, we present some milestones that are useful to get an introduction to the problems discussed below and a general vision of the whole work. We start with an overview of different types of prostheses and the general problems and challenges associated with their use and control; at the end of the chapter, we list all the contributions made by previous work in this area on data, analysis and algorithms; in Chapter 3, we describe the NinaPro experiment, which collected kinematic, dynamic and electromyographic data from intact and amputated subjects and built up the database we used in our experiments; in Chapter 1, we describe in detail the collection protocol, used devices, and data collection; in the second part, we describe the generally followed way of processing and displaying raw data in this area; and Chapter 4 focuses on the learning algorithms used in this work to solve the problem of detecting and classifying different movements.

sections.heading: A few landmarks
sections.text: Section 2.1 deals with various prostheses currently used by amputees. After a general introduction, we list the problems an amputated person faces when learning to use a prosthetic hand. Section 2.2 deals with challenges and questions that this work should solve. We explain the general approach and briefly the results achieved. Section 2.3 reports on a general vision and summary of all the work developed. Section 2.4 lists the most important work that has been done on the related problems.

sections.heading: 2.1 Prosthesis and control
sections.text: The most common non-invasive prostheses are: cosmetics, body-operated and myoelectric prostheses (Figure 2.1).11CHAPTER 2. A FEW AGRICULTURAL MARKETThe cosmetic ones are only aesthetic hands, they feel comfortable, but any kind of grasping or movement is forbidden.The body-operated ones are mechanical prostheses, they work with cables to connect the movement of the body with the prosthesis and control it. If an amputee moves the body in a certain way, he / she drives the cables, consequently the prosthetic hand is opened, closed or bent. Obviously, few movements can be performed to connect the body to the prosthesis and control it.

sections.heading: 2.2 Path in learning problems
sections.text: Controlling prostheses with non-invasive techniques, such as the myoelectric surface, is still a challenge today. In the bio-rehabilitation community, it is clear that the success of the myoelectric prosthesis is linked to the creation of a precise control system that allows patients to use it easily (see [8] and references to it).The method chosen to solve the problem is machine learning ([8], [10] and the references to it), which makes it possible to analyse the electromyographic signal using modern statistical techniques, such as neural networks and linear discrimination, in order to guess the movement that the subject wants to perform.

sections.heading: 2.3 Experimental framework
sections.text: We are now clearing all the passages to carry out an experiment aimed at controlling non-invasive myoelectric prostheses. We are looking at intact and amputated subjects from whom we collect electromyographic data. This data is collected by using surface electrodes placed as sensors on the last part of an amputee's arm or on the forearm of an intact subject. To achieve this goal, the input data is processed to remove a component of noise. In a second step, we extract useful information from the data to determine the discriminatory characteristics of the signal we want to classify. This process is called feature extraction. Data that is appropriately processed is used as input by various recognition algorithms. These algorithms solve in different ways a problem that we consider impossible to classify as a starting point by entering a signal.

sections.heading: 2.4 Previous works
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point where it only takes one year to get to the next round.

sections.heading: 3.1 Data description: the NinaPro database
sections.text: The NinaPro (Non Invasive Adaptive Prosthetics) database contains data and clinical information on 78 subjects: 67 intact and 11 transradial amputees. To our knowledge, it is the only existing public database with a consistent number of subjects, collected between 2011 and 2013. All data collection and database information can be found in [19], [20] and [21].

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Acquisition setup
sections.text: The mentioned persons are able to move, to move and to move.

sections.heading: 3.1.2 Acquisition protocol
sections.text: All experiments are approved by the Ethics Committee of the Canton of Valais (Switzerland). In the first step, several clinical data such as age, gender, height, weight and laterality are commented on. The remaining portion of the subjects is the ratio between the length of the amputated forearm and the length of the intact forearm from the elbow to the wrist, rounded down to the tenth. In the second step, the subjects are seated on an office chair. The remaining portion of the forearm is the ratio between the length of the amputated forearm and the length of the intact forearm, rounded down to the tenth. A laptop in front of the subjects shows with a film the exercises they must perform.

sections.heading: 3.2 Data representation: features extraction
sections.text: Online sEMG data requires some processes to make it available for classification, so we want to extract useful information from it to achieve this goal, a process known as feature extraction, which consists of several steps of pre-processing to purge data from the noise component and to select the algorithm for data representation. For a complete reading of this approach, refer to [22] and [23]. The described approach and processes are generally accepted in this area. In this thesis, we work with data from exercise 1 (17-hand configuration and wrist movements) of the second and third databases. Therefore, the reported parameter values are related to this analysis.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Preprocessing
sections.text: The initial data consist of a single continuous signal (one for each electrode) containing information about the sequence going from the first record to the last, interrupted by a rest position; the first step consists of the division of one movement from another; signals with different designations are separated; each resulting matrix identifies different movements or rest periods; the columns of this matrix are the channels (10 for the first database, 12 for the second and third); Figure 3.4 shows the motion division process; 263.2. DATA REPRESENTATION: FEATURES EXTRACTIONThe second operation is called windowing; each matrix from the previous point is divided into overlapping windows of fender length; the window length used in the literature is 100 ms, 200 ms and 400 ms; the shift of the observed edge is 10 ms ([23]).

sections.heading: 4.1 Mathematical framework and background
sections.text: In this section, we present mathematical tools necessary to do the rest of the work. In the following, we show column vectors with small bold letters, e.g. a = [a1, a2,..., aN] and matrices with bold uppercase letters, e.g. A-RM · N. With Ai, j, and Ai, we each designate the element (i, j) and the i-th column of matrix A. In the rest of the work, we refer to xi-X as the input vector of a learning algorithm, and to yi-Y as the corresponding output. X-R and Y = R are respectively the input space and the output space. We designate with D = {xi, yi} Ni = 1 a set of data that comes from an unknown probability distribution. The goal of a learning algorithm is to find a function that is identical for each future input vector i.

sections.heading: 4.2. SUPERVISED LEARNING ON A SINGLE DOMAIN
sections.text: Otherwise, the loss is linearly proportional to the differences between the trust values of the real class and the maximum trust that is related to another class. The aim of a learning problem is to minimize this risk.

sections.heading: 4.2 Supervised learning on a single domain
sections.text: We refer to training samples and test samples as a set of vectors or items for which we know the output classification, i.e. the label value. In a supervised learning problem, the first is used in the training phase to create a classification model; the second is used in the testing phase to evaluate the performance of a learning algorithm based on the match between the predicted labels and their real values. Thus, the learner receives a set of labeled examples as training data and makes predictions for all invisible points. In the following, we refer to N as the total number of training vectors. We define the target problem as the new classification problem we want to solve. In our case, it is the new subject that learns to perform some postures. In the simplest case, to create a classification model for the new target, we can only exploit the training data of the target itself.

sections.heading: 4.3 Support Vector Machines
sections.text: In this section we present one of the most effective classification algorithms in machine learning: Support Vector Machines (SVMs). The aim of the SVMs is to create a model that is able to predict the results of a given test vector based on the training data. [2], [3] and [7].35CHAPTER 4 are available for a full reading of the topics.

sections.heading: 4.3.2 Non-linear SVMs
sections.text: Until now, a linear decision boundary has been used to solve a classification problem. However, there are techniques that extend SVM algorithms to define non-linear decision boundaries.

sections.heading: 4.4 Supervised learning on a different domain
sections.text: So far, we are dealing with traditional learning, and one of the main assumptions on which it is based is that the training data used to learn the target model and the test data used to test this model come from the same distribution, but in many real-world problems, we can also use data from other areas (for example, from different data collections or databases collected with other devices), for example, we can have a model with little data available, and to avoid creating a not very solid model, we can also use data from other areas.

sections.heading: 4.5 Domain adaptation algorithms
sections.text: In fact, the fact is that most of them are able to move around without being able to move around to achieve their goals.

sections.heading: 4.5.1 Multi Adapt algorithm
sections.text: The first form of the Multi-Adapt algorithm was proposed in [10] and after the extension in [8]. It solves a classification problem by evaluating a combination of already known and correctly weighted source models. An optimization problem based on a non-linear SVM with Gaussian kernel is solved for each source, resulting in a vector w ² for each of these models. The basic idea is to find a solution to the new problem that is close to the solution presented. The optimization problem that we are tackling is the following: max w ² w − βw ² 2 + C 2 N ².

sections.heading: 4.5.2 Multi Kernel Adaptive Learning algorithm
sections.text: There are several types of algorithms that use a kernel combination to achieve better performance in the testing phase. [14], [15] and [15] describe the Multi-Kernel Adaptive Learning (MKAL) algorithm for a multiclass problem, as described in more detail in [5]. The weights of this linear combination reflect the meaning of each kernel. To introduce these algorithms, we define their final prediction as: h (x) = argmax g K = 1 βkg s (x, y), where the index k runs over classes and the index k over source. βkg are the weights of the score function sk (x, y) defined as: sk (x, y).

sections.heading: 4.5.3 High Level-Learning2Learn algorithm
sections.text: The algorithm High-Level-Learning2Learn (H-L2L) belongs to the high-level cue integration methods ([17] and [18]). This algorithm consists of two levels. In the first, the confidence is calculated for each source model and on a target model built with a multiclass LS-SVM. The vectors used to train the target model are part of the original training vectors (63% for each class). The used in the calculation of the trust are all the test vectors and the remaining training vectors (37% for each class). Thus, a vector x is used, for each initial class g we have the score starget (x, g) and K different scores ssource (x, g) in relation to: s (x, g) = the remaining training vectors (x) + bg. The vectors used to train the new model in the second level.

sections.heading: 5.1 Experimental protocol
sections.text: As I said, in this paper we have conducted three different experiments. In this section we describe the experimental settings common to each of them. We are looking at a target group that uses the previous knowledge of the source subjects to learn how to perform hand postures. Each experiment is explained in detail in the following sections: 20 in the first and 9 in the second and third. The source models under consideration are 19, 8 and 20 in each of the first, second and third stages. Each protocol is explained in detail in the following sections. The goal that a target group wants to achieve is to perform the same movements that source subjects are already able to do. For all experiments we are looking at the positions of Exercise B, i.e. 8 hand configurations and 9 basic movements of the wrist (see Section 3.1.3). Thus, for each goal we solve a classification problem a classification problem with 18 classes: 17 movements and posture. Each experiment has two phases: training and training.

sections.heading: Appendix A
sections.text: Histogram AnalysisThis analysis is performed to assess whether there is an adaptive method that recognizes one class better than others and whether this statistic changes and increases the number of training vectors. For each real class, we look at the four classes with the highest predictions to evaluate the differences in misclassification. Generally, the fifth predicted class has a recognition of less than 5%, which is why they and the following classes are not taken into account. Below, we analyze the results predicted for each true label.For the complete results, see https: / / sites.google.com / site / noninvasive rosthetics /.A.1 Histogram: First Experiment We report the histogram of the first four classes predicted for each true label.Methods involved in this analysis Multi Adapt (Figure A.1), MKAL (Figure A.2) and H-L2L (Figure A.3) for 120 (i.e. Final Step), 160 (i.e.) and (i.e.) 2200 (i.e.).

These movements are very similar, so it is reasonable to expect a high degree of confusion between different postures. In bio-robotics and rehabilitation community it is clear that the success of myoelectric prosthesis is linked to the creation of an accurate control system to make them easy to use by the patient (see [8] and references therein).
The path generally chosen to tackle the problem is machine learning ([8], [9], [10] and references therein).
